metadata.guideline_reference: KNGF Guideline on Falls Prevention, AGS/BGS Falls Prevention Guidelines

patient_profile.name: Elisabeth (Bep) Jansen
patient_profile.living_situation: Lives alone in ground-floor apartment since husband died 2 years ago
patient_profile.hobbies: Previously: walking group, church activities, visiting grandchildren. Now mostly stays home.
patient_profile.referral_reason: Recurrent falls (3 in past 6 months), reduced mobility, family concerned

falls_history.most_recent_fall: 2 weeks ago - fell in bathroom getting up from toilet at night

fall_circumstances.activity: Getting up from toilet at night

falls_history.pattern: Mixed - some environmental, some balance-related, several at night

presenting_problem.patient_narrative: I've become so unsteady on my feet. It started after Henk died - I stopped going out as much and I suppose I got weaker. Now I'm scared to walk anywhere in case I fall again. My daughter wants me to move to a care home but I don't want to leave my apartment. I know I should walk more but what if I fall and nobody finds me? I've been using my husband's old walking stick but I'm not sure I'm using it right.
presenting_problem.family_concerns: Daughter visits twice weekly, noticed mother has lost weight, seems frailer, more confused at times, and is isolating herself. Worried about safety living alone.

medical_history.polypharmacy_note: 6 medications including sedative hypnotic (zopiclone) and SSRI - both independently associated with increased fall risk
surgical_history: Right total knee replacement (8 years ago)

observation.general_appearance: Thin, appears older than stated age, mild kyphosis
observation.mobility_aids: Using single-point cane (husband's - not fitted to her)
observation.posture: Increased thoracic kyphosis, forward head position
observation.facial_expression: Looks anxious, avoids eye contact initially

vital_signs.clinical_note: Orthostatic hypotension present - contributor to falls

gait_assessment.observation: Slow, shuffling gait, reduced arm swing, short stride, wide base, looks at feet

gait_speed_10mwt.interpretation: Below community ambulation threshold (<0.8 m/s), indicates limited community mobility and frailty marker

gait_assessment.assistive_device_use: Using cane in wrong hand (left - should be right for left knee), incorrect height

berg_balance_scale.interpretation: Medium fall risk (41-56 low risk, 21-40 medium, 0-20 high)

timed_up_and_go.interpretation: High fall risk (>14 sec = fall risk)
timed_up_and_go.observations: Difficulty rising from chair, needs multiple attempts, unsteady turning

functional_reach.interpretation: Fall risk (<25 cm indicates increased fall risk)

mini_best_test.interpretation: All balance subsystems affected, particularly reactive and dynamic gait

five_times_sit_to_stand.interpretation: Indicates weakness and fall risk (>12 sec concerning)
five_times_sit_to_stand.observation: Uses arms to push up, forward trunk lean

grip_strength.interpretation: Below cut-off for sarcopenia (<16 kg for women)

sensory_assessment.vision: Wears glasses, reports difficulty seeing in low light (macular degeneration)
sensory_assessment.vibration_sense: Reduced at great toes bilateral (possible diabetic neuropathy)
sensory_assessment.proprioception: Intact at ankles but mildly reduced at toes

cognitive_screening.clinical_implications: May affect ability to learn new strategies, follow complex instructions, remember exercises

sppb.interpretation: Low performance, indicates frailty and high risk

frailty_assessment.clinical_frailty_scale: 5 - Mildly frail (slowed, needs help with IADLs)

fes_i.interpretation: High concern about falling (range 16-64, >28 = high concern)

fear_of_falling.activity_avoidance: Reports avoiding going outside, avoiding stairs, only bathes when daughter visits
fear_of_falling.clinical_note: Fear of falling is leading to activity avoidance, which is worsening physical capacity - vicious cycle

extrinsic_factors.evidence: Home assessment needed - falls in bathroom

activity_limitations.qualifier_description: Severe problem - avoids stairs, outdoor mobility restricted
Moderate problem - only bathes with help

participation_restrictions.qualifier_description: Severe problem - stopped walking group, church
Severe problem - cannot visit, afraid to hold grandchildren

environmental_factors.qualifier_description: Mild barrier - no grab rails, inappropriate footwear

personal_factors.motivation: Wants to stay independent and in her home
personal_factors.grief: Still grieving husband - affects mood and activity
personal_factors.independence_identity: Strong desire to remain independent - was a nurse, used to helping others

problems.activity_limitation: Unsafe and slow ambulation (gait speed 0.6 m/s, TUG 18 sec) with high fall risk
problems.participation_impact: Unable to safely mobilize in community, social isolation

problems.activity_limitation: Avoiding activities due to fear of falling (FES-I 42)
underlying_impairments: Perceived inability to cope with fall
problems.participation_impact: Social isolation, stopped walking group and church, declining physical capacity

problems.activity_limitation: Difficulty rising from chair/toilet requiring use of arms and multiple attempts
problems.participation_impact: Depends on daughter for bathing, fears toilet transfers at night
Falls at home, unsafe to be alone

long_term_goal.goal: Remain living safely at home with reduced fall risk, improved mobility, and resumed social activities (walking group OR church)

short_term_goals.goal: Home modifications completed (grab rails in bathroom, improved lighting, appropriate footwear obtained)
Fitted with appropriate walking aid (rollator) and educated on correct use
Complete sit-to-stand without using arms for push-off (5xSTS <15 sec)
Walk 10 meters in <12 seconds (gait speed ≥0.8 m/s) with rollator
Resume one social activity outside the home (walking group or church) with confidence

intervention_plan.treatment_approach: Multifactorial falls prevention addressing strength, balance, fear of falling, home hazards, and medications. Gradual, confidence-building approach.

interventions.intervention: Progressive lower limb and functional strengthening
exercises: Sit-to-stand practice (progress from high chair to normal height to without arms)
interventions.dosage: 3x/week in clinic initially, daily home exercises
interventions.evidence: Strong - Otago exercise program reduces falls by 35%

interventions.intervention: Progressive static and dynamic balance exercises
interventions.dosage: Incorporated into every session + home program

focus: Head up, not looking at feet
interventions.dosage: Daily walking practice, gradually increase distance

interventions.intervention: Cognitive-behavioral approach and graded activity exposure
strategies: Education - falls are not inevitable, strength improves
Discuss what she would do if she fell (getting up from floor practice)
interventions.evidence: Moderate - CBT-based programs reduce fear of falling
interventions.coaching_note: Fear of falling is as important to address as physical impairments

recommendations: Grab rails in bathroom (toilet and shower)
Night lights for path to bathroom
Consider commode or urinal for night-time

interventions.intervention: Fit and train with appropriate walking aid
interventions.recommendation: Four-wheeled rollator (more stable than cane, has seat for rest)
interventions.rationale: Provides more support than cane, addresses multiple balance deficits, seat allows for rest breaks
interventions.training: Correct height, posture, turning, use of brakes, sitting on seat

interventions.intervention: Communicate with GP regarding fall-risk medications
concerns: Zopiclone - sedative hypnotic, strong association with falls
interventions.recommendation: Letter to GP requesting medication review with focus on fall risk
interventions.pt_role: Identify and communicate concerns, not prescribe

strategies: Sit on edge of bed before standing

topics: Falls are not inevitable - they can be prevented
Importance of staying active (deconditioning worsens fall risk)
Getting up from a fall safely
interventions.involve_daughter: Include in education sessions, discuss safety plan

plan_of_care.frequency: 2x/week for 6 weeks, then weekly for 6 weeks
plan_of_care.follow_up: Falls prevention group or ongoing community exercise

gp_communication.purpose: Medication review, orthostatic hypotension management, depression review
gp_communication.information_to_share: Fall risk assessment findings, medication concerns, orthostatic hypotension

occupational_therapy.purpose: Home assessment, ADL training, equipment recommendation

ophthalmology.purpose: Review macular degeneration management, ensure optimal vision correction

social_services.purpose: Community support, day programs, personal alarm

reasoning_traps_for_this_case.description: Accepting falls as inevitable consequence of aging rather than identifying modifiable factors
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.coaching_response: You've noted she's 81 and has had falls. Are falls inevitable at this age? What modifiable risk factors have you identified?

reasoning_traps_for_this_case.description: Focusing only on physical impairments without addressing the fear component
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.coaching_response: Her FES-I is 42 and she's avoiding activities. How might fear of falling be affecting her physical capacity? Is this a treatment target?

reasoning_traps_for_this_case.description: Overlooking the contribution of zopiclone and other medications to fall risk
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.coaching_response: You've listed her medications. Which ones might contribute to fall risk? What's your role in addressing this?

reasoning_traps_for_this_case.description: Only treating the patient without addressing home hazards
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.coaching_response: She fell in the bathroom at night. What environmental modifications might reduce her fall risk at home?

reasoning_traps_for_this_case.description: Telling patient to be careful and avoid activities to prevent falls
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.coaching_response: If we advise her to stay home and avoid walking, what will happen to her strength and balance over time? Is activity avoidance protective?

reasoning_traps_for_this_case.description: Treating patient in isolation without engaging daughter in care planning
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.coaching_response: The daughter visits twice weekly and is concerned. How might you involve her in the rehabilitation plan?

reasoning_traps_for_this_case.description: Providing balance exercises alone without addressing the multifactorial nature of falls
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.coaching_response: You've prescribed balance exercises. What other fall risk factors need to be addressed for a comprehensive approach?

step_1_data_collection: What intrinsic, extrinsic, and behavioral risk factors did you identify?
What does the gait speed of 0.6 m/s tell you about community mobility and frailty?
The TUG is 18 seconds - what is the clinical significance?
What does the FES-I score tell you? Why is this important?
What medications might be contributing to fall risk?
step_2_problem_statements: You've listed 'poor balance' as a problem. Can you reframe this as an activity limitation?
How does the fear of falling connect to her social isolation?
What is the relationship between her activity avoidance and her physical decline?
step_3_goal_setting: Your goal is 'prevent falls' - is this measurable? How would you make it SMART?
What functional activities does the patient want to resume?
Are your goals realistic given her cognitive status? How will you ensure she can follow the program?
step_4_intervention_selection: Why did you choose the Otago exercise program?
How will you address the fear of falling component?
What environmental modifications would you recommend?
What will you communicate to the GP about medications?
step_7_reevaluation: What outcome measures will you use to track progress?
How will you know if the fear of falling is improving?
What would indicate the program is successful?

key_education_messages: Falls are not a normal part of aging - they can be prevented
Staying active is protective - being too careful and avoiding activity actually increases fall risk over time
Strength and balance can be improved at any age
Simple home modifications can significantly reduce fall risk
If you do fall, knowing how to get up safely is important (we'll practice this)
There are strategies to manage dizziness when standing up
